snippet: As many as 500,000 Iraqis fled Mosul after a militant group swarmed the city, many of them Sunnis who seemed less fearful of the group than their own government.
abstract: Many Iraqis who fled Mosul after it was besieged by extremist group Islamic State in Iraq and Syria are returning, preferring to take their chances under militant group so violent it was thrown out of Al Qaeda; fact illustrates how difficult it will be for Iraqi government to reassert control, as any aggressive effort by Baghdad to retake the city could reinforce Iraqi Army's reputation as occupying force.

byline.contributor: Falih Hassan and Suadad al-Salhy contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: As many as 500,000 Iraqis fled Mosul after a militant group swarmed the city, many of them Sunnis who seemed less fearful of the group than their own government.

headline.main: Iraqis Who Fled Mosul Say They Prefer Militants to Government
headline.print_headline: Choosing Rebels Over Army, Iraqis Head Home

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
keywords.name: subject

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
